course_title: Foundations of Physiotherapy I: Fundamentals of Communication, Movement & Exercise

learning_outcomes.description: Describe the scope of physiotherapy as a profession and its role within the wider interprofessional health care team.
Describe and apply the principles of client- and family-centred care in physiotherapy practice.
Describe and apply the principles of cultural safety, disability inclusion and psychosocial awareness in physiotherapy practice.
Demonstrate effective communication skills in physiotherapy practice.
Describe human development from birth to adulthood.
Engage in reflective practice to recognise personal and cultural influences on learning and professional practice, and implement strategies for ongoing development.
Demonstrate safe, effective, and comfortable patient handling and positioning for both patients and physiotherapists.
Choose, explain and apply soft tissue manipulation techniques safely and effectively for patients with a wide range of conditions.
Choose, explain and apply electrotherapeutic agents safely and effectively for patients with a wide range of conditions.
Engage in reflective practice to recognise personal and cultural influences on learning and professional practice, and implement strategies for ongoing development.

assessments.task_description:
During this practical examination students will be assessed on their ability to communicate as well as safely and effectively apply soft tissue mobilisation and electrophysical agent treatment techniques. All practical skills and theoretical knowledge will be examinable.

You will rotate between stations, for a total of 60 minutes. Further details will be provided on blackboard. 

Individual written feedback, as well as written and/or oral group feedback will be provided by the course coordinator. Requests for further feedback must be submitted in writing to the course coordinator and must include a reflective statement on exam performance, identifying strengths and areas of difficulty. Feedback will be provided within the summer teaching semester.

In this course the recording of an assessment (oral/practical) performance has been waived, a record of student performance will be taken by other means such as audio recording or detailed written notes that can be referred to if a remark is required at a later date.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This written examination will be held in-person, online in the final week of class time prior to the Christmas break. It will cover:

  • Professional Foundations, 
  • Posture & Movement, 
  • Soft Tissue Mobilization, 
  • Electrophysical Agents

UQ uses the assessment tool, Inspera Assessment, in this course. Inspera Assessment provides additional functionality to complement the existing suite of digital learning tools at UQ with a greater range of question types and accessibility provisions. Further details, including an introduction to Inspera functionality, practice opportunities, and where to go for support, will be provided via Blackboard during semester. You MUST bring an appropriate device (per Blackboard instructions) to complete the exam. Failure to review the information regarding device requirements may result in being unable to complete the exam, resulting in a fail grade.

Written and oral group feedback will be provided by the course coordinator. Requests for individual feedback must be submitted in writing to the course coordinator and must include a reflective statement on exam performance, identifying strengths and areas of difficulty. Feedback will be provided within the summer teaching semester.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Independent Learning

Students will engage in a range of independent learning activities designed to build their understanding of course content. These include:

  • Pre-recorded lectures: Flexible access to key theoretical concepts and frameworks.
  • Online learning packages: Interactive modules providing opportunities to apply knowledge, review key material, and check understanding.
  • Independent tasks: Structured activities such as guided readings, case studies, and reflection tasks to consolidate learning and prepare for workshops and assessments.


Independent learning allows students to work at their own pace, revisit complex material, and take responsibility for deepening their knowledge and skills outside of scheduled class time. Relevant content must be completed prior to the related in-person practical classes.

learning_activities.topic:
In-person lectures

Lectures delivered on campus provide opportunities for interactive learning through real-time discussion, clarification of complex concepts, and active engagement through questions and group activities. These sessions may not be recorded due to the nature of activities.
learning_activities.topic_description: In-person lectures Lectures delivered on campus provide opportunities for interactive learning through real-time discussion, clarification of complex concepts, and active engagement through questions and group activities. These sessions may not be recorded due to the nature of activities.

learning_activities.topic:
Practical sessions

Practical classes provide hands-on opportunities to develop essential physiotherapy skills such as soft tissue mobilisation, patient positioning, use of electrotherapeutic agents, movement analysis, and professional communication. Learning occurs through demonstration, guided practice, and individualised feedback. Sessions are led by a lead educator with additional tutors providing close supervision, individualised guidance, and small-group feedback to support skill development and confidence in clinical application.
